supporting_text: The plan is focusing on five major elements with defined objectives, activities and monitoring tools by adopting the One Health approach.
The NAP includes specific actions in the human health sector, including promoting rational use of antimicrobial agents at all healthcare levels.
The NAP includes actions targeting animal health, such as prohibiting the use of Critically Important Antibiotics in animals and requiring prescriptions for antimicrobials used in food animals.
The document does not explicitly mention strategies or actions targeting the environment.
The NAP includes actions related to agriculture, such as monitoring antimicrobial usage in food animals and implementing standards published by OIE.
The NAP mentions that annual reports of all activities should be submitted to the National AMR committee.
The document does not specify any time-bound targets.
The document does not provide quantitative targets for AMR prevalence or antimicrobial use.
The document does not mention any specific budget allocation for the strategies.
The document does not contain an assessment of future budget requirements.
The NAP mentions the establishment of a National AMR Committee composed of various stakeholders for coordination.
The NAP includes legalizations to link dispensing of all antimicrobial agents to a prescription and to prohibit over-the-counter sales.
The NAP includes actions to include the importance of rational use of antimicrobials in the curricula of nursing, pharmacy, dental, medical, and veterinary schools.
The NAP mentions conducting regular national campaigns to increase awareness among healthcare workers, veterinary professionals, and the public.
The NAP emphasizes the need for international collaboration with organizations such as WHO, FAO, and OIE.
The NAP includes establishing a national reference center for antimicrobial resistance capable of systematic data collection and analysis.
The NAP mentions the need to upgrade laboratory capacity to identify newly or emerging mechanisms of resistance.
The NAP includes activities to ensure high standards of infection prevention and control to minimize the risk of infection.
The NAP mentions adapting the FAO/WHO Codex Alimentarius Code of practice to minimize and contain AMR in animal health and agriculture sectors.
The NAP includes legalizations to link dispensing of all antimicrobial agents to a prescription.
The NAP includes legal requirements for manufacturers to collect and report data on antimicrobial distribution.
The NAP emphasizes the need for collaborative research sectors including healthcare, drug regulatory agencies, and veterinary care.
